repnme.cdata!:
Ethiopia - Electricity Access (Rural)
            Expansion Project and Energy Access Project - redacted report

abstracts.cdata!:
This report on the Electricity Access
            (Rural) Expansion Project, and Energy Access Project of
            Ethiopia provides the findings of an INT administrative
            inquiry (the Investigation) into allegations of corrupt,
            fraudulent, collusive, and/or coercive practices, as defined
            by the WBG for purposes of its own policies, rules and
            procedures (the WBG's Framework regarding
            Anti-corruption), in relation to the WBG-supported
            activities. The purpose of the Investigation was to allow
            the WBG to determine if the WBG's Framework regarding
            Anti-corruption has been violated. This Report is being
            shared to ensure that its recipients are aware of the
            results of the INT Investigation.

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Electricity Access
            (Rural) Expansion Project for Ethiopia were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was substantial; Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory and borrower performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned includes:
            identification of all risks and mitigation measures is
            critical. If the project had considered the risk of delays
            in construction of these power plants, the Bank and the
            Government of Ethiopia (GoE) could have discussed and agreed
            on mitigation measures at the outset. A stalemate can be
            resolved through a win-win solution. While the GoE imposed a
            moratorium on new connections and did not agree to
            restructure the project to change its Project Development
            Objective (PDO), the Bank task team and Ethiopian Electric
            Power Corporation (EEPCo) identified a solution that worked
            for all. Quick growth creates capacity constraints. To meet
            the GoE's growth vision, EEPCo grew fast, from 800,000
            consumers in 2006 to 2 million consumers in 2009. Projects
            must anchor ownership of technical assistance and Monitoring
            and Evaluation (M&E) components solidly with the client.
            EEPCo did not extend the contract of the internationally
            recruited supervising engineer when it expired and argued
            that all required supervision could be done by in-house staff.

repnme.cdata!:
Ethiopia - First Phase of the Electricity
            Access (Rural) Expansion Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the First
            Phase of the Electricity Access (Rural) Expansion Project is
            to establish a sustainable program for expanding access to
            electricity in rural communities, thus supporting
            broad-based economic development and helping alleviate
            poverty. The changes consist of: 1) reallocation of proceeds
            to compensate for over expenditures in two categories and to
            provide adequate funding for expanded activities; 2) design
            changes in component three of the project to respond to
            client demand and improve implementation performance; and 3)
            modification of the results monitoring table to improve the
            outcome orientation of the indicators and to reflect the
            increase in target values as a result of restructuring.

display_title.display_title:
Ethiopia - First Phase of the
            Electricity Access (Rural) Expansion Project : restructuring
            : Main report

repnme.cdata!:
Ethiopia - Accelerated Electricity Access
            (Rural) Expansion Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Accelerated Electricity Access (Rural) Expansion Project for
            Ethiopia is to establish a sustainable program for expanding
            access to electricity in rural communities, thus supporting
            broad-based economic development and helping alleviate
            poverty. The closing date for the project will be extended
            from June 30, 2011 until December 31, 2012. The credit is
            for 92.8 million SDR, from which 52.2 million SDRs have been
            disbursed. The project is recovering now from a slow start
            caused by procurement problems and a moratorium on
            connections, which was lifted in September 2010. Good
            progress has been made with 204 towns of 380 having been
            connected; 5 million compact fluorescent lamps distributed
            under the energy efficiency component, and much of the
            technical assistance has been rendered. The extension is
            necessary to allow sufficient time for completion of project
            activities which were delayed due to procurement problems
            and the connection moratorium declared as a result of the
            drought-induced power crisis. The borrower has an action
            plan in place to ensure timely completion of all outstanding
            activities under the project. The balance of towns will be
            electrified as per this plan.

display_title.display_title:
Ethiopia - Accelerated
            Electricity Access (Rural) Expansion Project : restructuring
            (Vol. 2) : Data sheet
